data.title: Mayor Greenberg Provides Weekly Update
data.meta_description: Editor's note: Photos from today's event can be found here.
data.text:
Editor's note: Photos from today's event can be found here.

LOUISVILLE, KY – During his weekly update Tuesday Mayor Craig Greenberg provided an update on a Comprehensive Cultural Plan with Louisville Metro’s Office of Arts + Creative Industries, highlighted a Louisville bar recently named one of USA TODAY’s best bars in America, announced a new Executive Director of the Office of Equity, and recognized one of the city’s most celebrated organizations, St. Joseph Children’s Home.

Comprehensive Cultural Plan

Designing Local, a Columbus, Ohio-based consulting firm recently won an RFP to create a Comprehensive Cultural Plan for Louisville through Louisville Metro’s Office of Arts + Creative Industries. This will include an audit of Louisville’s creative economy and an update to the Public Art Master Plan. The Office of Arts + Creative Industries will be working closely with Designing Local over the next year to engage the Louisville community in establishing a strategic roadmap for arts and culture initiatives across the city for the next ten years.

“The Office of Arts + Creative Industries is excited to undertake this important work on behalf of the city. But it is essential that it be done in collaboration with residents, artists, and cultural practitioners which is why it was critical to find the right consultant to partner with us in facilitating this process,” said Jessica Bennett Kincaid, Arts + Creative Industries Director.

Designing Local is an award-winning firm who has worked with communities across the country. Members of the team are in Louisville this week to get further acquainted with Louisville’s art scene and begin identifying stakeholders. The firm’s design for the future Cultural Plan will be informed by local research, community input and national benchmarks. The planning process will take a closer look at the role the creative sector plays in our city’s overall economy, which includes non-profit and private sector employment data, salaries, sales, and tax revenue impact.

To encourage vibrant dialogue around arts and culture, residents can fill out this form to make sure their voice is heard. The firm will facilitate at least two community meetings to guide the crafting of a plan that reflects Louisville’s voice and values. The Office of Arts + Creative industries will announce when the first meeting will be scheduled.

The Office of Arts + Creative Industries also noted that Louisville Metro has updated the External Agency Fund grant program which will provide more support for the arts and culture community. Bennett Kincaid announced that her office will be accepting applications for $125,000 in grant funds available to local arts and culture non-profits. For more information, NEA Grants for Arts Projects Sub-Grant | LouisvilleKY.gov Interested applicants can click on the link, and then click on the drop-down for “Applicant Orientation,” which will have the Webex information.

NEAT Bourbon Bar & Bottle Shop Named One of USA TODAY’s Bars of the Year

Neat Bourbon Bar & Bottle Shop, a beloved destination for bourbon enthusiasts from across the country, has been honored as one of the 27 bars included in the 2024 USA TODAY Bars of the Year list. This prestigious list, curated by USA TODAY Network food writers, features a diverse range of establishments from humble dives to high-end cocktail bars across America.

“Congratulations to NEAT Bourbon Bar & Bottle Shop for being named one of the USA Today’s Bars of the Year,” said Mayor Greenberg. “Your passion for providing a unique and exceptional experience adds cultural and economic vibrancy to the Bardstown Road corridor. Cheers to your continued success!”

Located in the heart of the Highlands, Neat Bourbon Bar & Bottle Shop has quickly become a staple stop for both locals and tourists since its establishment in 2022. Known for its vintage bourbon selection and one of the best old-fashioned cocktails in town, Neat offers a unique experience that blends history with exceptional quality.

St. Joseph Children’s Home

St. Joseph Children’s Home has been a pillar of the Louisville community since 1849 and is celebrating 175 years of dedicated service to Kentucky families. Established in downtown Louisville, St. Joe’s was created to care for children whose families experienced hardships like typhoid, cholera, and challenging work conditions in the mid 1800’s. Since then, St. Joe’s has remained steadfast in its mission to support children in need.

“St. Joseph Children’s Home has always been for the kids,” said Suzy Hillebrand, Chief Advancement Officer. “We stand on a rich 175-year history of serving Kentucky children and families through our programs and will continue to do so until every child has a safe home and a bright future in our diverse community.”

St. Joe’s serves approximately 300 children each month through these programs, and since its inception, has cared for over 75,000 children. To commemorate this milestone, St. Joe’s will host its 175th Picnic on August 9th and 10th. The community is invited to attend and celebrate the legacy and future of St. Joe’s. Click here for more information about St. Joseph Children’s Home.

Dr. Vanessa McPhail joins the Mayor’s Office

Mayor Greenberg recently announced the new Executive Director of the Office of Equity, Dr. Vanessa McPhail, who will serve as Metro Government’s leader for improving racial equity across Metro Government and beyond.

Dr. McPhail joins the Office of Equity from JCPS, where she most recently served as the community affairs specialist in the district’s Diversity, Equity, and Poverty Department. Dr. McPhail started with JCPS in 2006 as a middle school teacher and served in a variety of roles building world-class education training systems with a specialty in restorative practices and positive behavior intervention supports. Throughout her 19-year career Dr. McPhail has successfully established relationships with local government, community agencies and nonprofit organizations that improved student and district outcomes with a focus on racial equity. Dr. McPhail earned her EdD from the University of Louisville in 2019.

“Dr. McPhail is an incredible leader who brings extensive knowledge and experience to the Mayor’s Office and the Office of Equity,” said Mayor Greenberg. “I know she will work tirelessly to expand access to opportunities for historically marginalized and disenfranchised populations, which is in line with our commitment to advancing racial equity within Metro Government and beyond.”

In her new role, McPhail will lead the city’s efforts to improve racial equity across all departments within Metro Government, working with employees and department leaders to improve policies and strategic partnerships while achieving equitable outcomes and opportunities for everyone in Metro Government.
